name: Kepler-84
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-84 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-84 is a star with 1.3039999999999998 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.17 times its radius. It is located 4707.31 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-84 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-84 d

Kepler-84 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.22 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-84.

The mass of Kepler-84 d is 2.08 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-84 d is 1.38 that of Earth. At 2.08 Earth masses, Kepler-84 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-84 e

Kepler-84 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 27.43 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-84.

The mass of Kepler-84 e is 9.54 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-84 e is 2.6 that of Earth. At 9.54 Earth masses, Kepler-84 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-84 f

Kepler-84 f was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.25 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 44.55 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-84.

The mass of Kepler-84 f is 6.36 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-84 f is 2.2 that of Earth. At 6.36 Earth masses, Kepler-84 f is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-84, which contains 5 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
